We are using a 6 motor WCD with 4 Victors and 2 Talons for encoders. When we drive forwards and backwards it’s fine but when we turn it inverts the talons.

So we have 3 motors on each gearbox and the 2 motors using victors operate as they should. However whenever I try to turn the one motor using the Talon reverses and fights the other 2 motors in the gearbox. But when driving forwards or reverse everything works fine other than that I haven’t reversed one side yet to make it not just spin.

here’s the code drop.

you probably have one of the left/right can IDs mixed up, so when you go forward/backward the motors spin the same direction, but when you turn the motor that is on the wrong side is fighting the other two.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T04:24:28.613Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":110,"readers_count":109,"score":27.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":423946,"topic_slug":"talon-inverts-when-turning","display_username":"Sean B","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":49593,"username":"Konnor","name":"Konnor/RetroBuzz | 5517AM","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/konnor/{size}/246214_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44845,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lone Coder"},"post_url":"/t/talon-inverts-when-turning/423946/8","custom_user_title":"Lone Coder","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3130375,"name":"Andy Gasser","username":"gdefender","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T04:58:45.049Z","cooked":"

I don’t see a problem with your code that would cause the problem. @Phlogiston is probably right. Check your controller CAN IDs with Phoenix Tuner.

I do have some feedback on a few things in your code. You might want to take a look at the WPILib page Structuring a Command-Based Robot Project

  • The fields in RobotContainer and DriveTrain should not be static and they should be private.
    – Static fields belong to the class as a whole, where non-static fields belong to an instance of the class. Here is a decent tutorial on the difference.
    – The motor controllers (Talons and Victors) in DriveTrain should not be static and they should be private. Your public methods, such as arcadeDrive should provide functionality that uses the motor controllers.
    – RobotContainer should construct your commands and pass the dependent subsystems into the command’s constructor.
  • You don’t really need three different commands for ArcadeDrive, Boost, and Slow. You can have a single ArcadeDrive command that does not call baseSpeed, boost, or slow, but instead bind those methods to the buttons on the controller. You don’t need to repeated call those methods, one call will change the speed until another call is made.
  • The Brakes command doesn’t look right. It should not set the idle mode in its constructor. If it is supposed to toggle the idle mode you probably want to set the neutral mode to Brake in the initialize method, and set it to Coast in the end method. Additionally, you should add a method or methods to DriveTrain to allow the idle mode to be toggled, since the motor controllers should be private.

Yea the CAN ID thing sounds like it will work I just started using the new Pheonix Tuner X and right now our cables are a mess so I might of messed that up. Also I don’t really understand the whole static, public, private thing and the call the speedControl commands in the arcadeDrive command. Also its the first time I have tried making a toggle so I just put something in there real quick to see if it would work but the main DriveTrain issue came up first.

Do not do this; it will not behave how you expect it to. Your controllers should not be globally visible from your commands in the first place; typically we avoid static variables because they make things like this possible when you almost never want to do them (we call such things “footguns” in the industry).

Take a look at the new RapidReactCommandBot example project for some guidance on how to structure a command-based robot project for 2023.

Konnor:

Also I don’t really understand the whole static, public, private thing

You have to understand this to write anything other than a toy example program in Java. I strongly suggest spending some time reading tutorials on scoping before trying to progress further - these concepts are relevant in every language.

Konnor:

Is this what you mean by binding them in the arcadeDrive command.

No, that will cause the commands to be bound over and over again when the ArcadeDrive command is run.

  1. Delete the Brakes, Boost, and Slow commands.
  2. I like CommandXBoxController because it makes binding easy. Also, it makes it easy to read, I don’t know which button 5 is without looking it up.
    In RobotContainer replace:
public static XboxController xboxController = new XboxController(OIConstants.xboxController);

with this (notice it’s also private, not public static):

private CommandXboxController xboxController = new CommandXboxController(OIConstants.xboxController);
  1. Add a method to DriveTrain to set the idle mode to coast (and I renamed the brake mode method)
  public void setIdleBrake() {
    rightMotorID0.setNeutralMode(NeutralMode.Brake);
    rightMotorID1.setNeutralMode(NeutralMode.Brake);
    rightTalonID2.setNeutralMode(NeutralMode.Brake);
    leftMotorID3.setNeutralMode(NeutralMode.Brake);
    leftMotorID4.setNeutralMode(NeutralMode.Brake);
    leftTalonID5.setNeutralMode(NeutralMode.Brake);
  }

  public void setIdleCoast() {
    rightMotorID0.setNeutralMode(NeutralMode.Coast);
    rightMotorID1.setNeutralMode(NeutralMode.Coast);
    rightTalonID2.setNeutralMode(NeutralMode.Coast);
    leftMotorID3.setNeutralMode(NeutralMode.Coast);
    leftMotorID4.setNeutralMode(NeutralMode.Coast);
    leftTalonID5.setNeutralMode(NeutralMode.Coast);
  }
  1. Finally, in RobotContainer, bind the drivetrain methods to buttons on the controller. If this code doesn’t make sense, take a look at Organizing Command-Based Robot Projects > Defining Commands
  private void configureBindings() {
    m_drivetrain.setDefaultCommand(new ArcadeDrive());
    xboxController.leftBumper().onTrue(Commands.runOnce(m_drivetrain::slow));
    xboxController.rightBumper().onTrue(Commands.runOnce(m_drivetrain::boost));
    xboxController.a().toggleOnTrue(Commands.startEnd(m_drivetrain::setIdleBrake, m_drivetrain::setIdleCoast));
  }

Also, you should make your motor controllers in DriveTrain private and not static. If this breaks your code, you should fix the code that’s improperly accessing the controllers, probably by adding public methods. Do not expose them as public.

  private WPI_VictorSPX rightMotorID0 = new WPI_VictorSPX(DriveConstants.rightVictorID0);
  private WPI_VictorSPX rightMotorID1 = new WPI_VictorSPX(DriveConstants.rightVictorID1);
  private WPI_TalonSRX rightTalonID2 = new WPI_TalonSRX(DriveConstants.rightTalonID2);
  private MotorControllerGroup rightMotors = new MotorControllerGroup(rightMotorID0, rightMotorID1, rightTalonID2);
  private WPI_VictorSPX leftMotorID3 = new WPI_VictorSPX(DriveConstants.leftVictorID3);
  private WPI_VictorSPX leftMotorID4 = new WPI_VictorSPX(DriveConstants.leftVictorID4);
  private WPI_TalonSRX leftTalonID5 = new WPI_TalonSRX(DriveConstants.leftTalonID5);
  private MotorControllerGroup leftMotors = new MotorControllerGroup(leftMotorID3, leftMotorID4, leftTalonID5);
  private DifferentialDrive drive = new DifferentialDrive(leftMotors, rightMotors);

EDIT: You also need to remove m_driveTrain.baseSpeed() from ArcadeDrive.execute() or you will constantly set the speed back to the base speed. I suppose you will want to bind this method to another button, so you can get out of fast or slow mode. I missed that because your original code also provided no way to get back into the base speed.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T17:42:53.198Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":67,"readers_count":66,"score":23.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":423946,"topic_slug":"talon-inverts-when-turning","display_username":"Andy Gasser","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/commandbased/organizing-command-based.html#defining-commands","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Organizing Command-Based Robot Projects — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44380,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/talon-inverts-when-turning/423946/13","custom_user_title":"7028 - Java Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3130600,"name":"Sean B","username":"Phlogiston","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/phlogiston/{size}/180763_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T17:11:18.928Z","cooked":"

Here’s a simplified explanation of the keywords:
public means that you can directly access the variable from outside the class, but only from an instance of the class (e.g. “new MyClass().myVariable”).

static means that the variable can be accessed without an instance of the class, and is the same across all instances (e.g. “MyClass.myVariable”, which is what you are doing for your variables in RobotContainer). This breaks the idea of packaging things into classes. The RobotContainer should “own” the different subsystems and controllers of the robot. Pretty much the ONLY place you should have static variables is in Constants.java, just to keep all the physical robot properties in one file.

private only allows the variable to be accessed within the class it was declared in. This is beneficial because it allows you to ensure the variable’s value will always be what it is supposed to be. It prevents you from writing a class that works perfectly, and then writing another class that modifies a variable in the first class in an unexpected way. Of course, you still need the data from that variable, so you can write a “getter” function that returns the value - this lets data from the variable get out of a class, without allowing erroneous data in. If the value needs to be changed as well, you can also have a setter function, and maybe have some checks to make sure the value is acceptable.

final makes the variable “immutable” meaning that once it is set to a value, it can’t be changed.

Most variables in FRC code should be private and final. For example, motor controllers should be private because other classes should never need direct access to the motor controller (that defeats the purpose of subsystems), and final because if you write another motor controller to the same variable, you are either breaking something or wasting resources.

Adding a getter to RobotContainer would require a RobotContainer instance to be passed to the command. This is not correct. You should pass the XBoxController to the command (or better yet, pass suppliers to the command.) The documentation linked above mentions this, it is called “dependency injection.”

This would look something like this:

public class ArcadeDrive extends CommandBase {

  private final DriveTrain m_driveTrain;
  private final CommandXboxController m_xboxController;

  public ArcadeDrive(CommandXboxController xboxController, DriveTrain driveTrain) {
    this.m_xboxController = xboxController;
    this.m_driveTrain = driveTrain;

    addRequirements(driveTrain);
  }

  @Override
  public void execute() {
    double forwardSpeed = -m_xboxController.getLeftY();
    double rotationSpeed = -m_xboxController.getRightX();
    m_driveTrain.arcadeDrive(forwardSpeed, rotationSpeed);
    // m_driveTrain.baseSpeed(); EDIT: DO NOT DO THiS
  }

...
}

Also notice that I inverted the controller inputs. Y up on an XBoxController is negative, and robot rotation is counter-clockwise positive. Without these inversions the robot will drive and spin “backwards”.

gdefender:

You should pass the XBoxController to the command (or better yet, pass suppliers to the command.)

Yes I was being stupid this is the right way to do it.

Why would passing in the XboxController object be a better solution then passing in a DoubleSupplier for a drive command, like the following:

public class DefaultDrive extends CommandBase {
  private final DriveSubsystem m_drive;
  private final DoubleSupplier m_forward;
  private final DoubleSupplier m_rotation;

  public DefaultDrive(DriveSubsystem _drive, DoubleSupplier _forward, DoubleSupplier _rotation) {
    m_drive = _drive;
    m_forward = _forward;
    m_rotation = _rotation;
    addRequirements(m_drive);
  }

  // Called every time the scheduler runs while the command is scheduled.
  @Override
  public void execute() {
    m_drive.arcadeDrive(m_forward.getAsDouble(), m_rotation.getAsDouble());
  }

}

With RobotContainer as:

    m_drive.setDefaultCommand(
        new DefaultDrive(m_drive, driverGamepad::getLeftY, driverGamepad::getRightX));

It could very well be I missed something between last year, and this year, but my interpretation was to pass a DoubleSupplier for the command, and not the Joystick

ChristianFemia:

Why would passing in the XboxController object be a better solution then passing in a DoubleSupplier for a drive command

I agree, passing the XBoxController is not a better solution. I said passing suppliers was “better yet.” I didn’t do it in the example because it requires an understanding of lambdas, so it’s more to grasp. But I agree, this is even better encapsulation and you’re only injecting the dependency you actually need.

EDIT: I noticed in your example that you’re not inverting the axis, this would be required to make the robot drive forward:

m_drive.setDefaultCommand(
        new DefaultDrive(m_drive, () -> -driverGamepad.getLeftY(), () -> -driverGamepad.getRightX()));
